document_data.name: Patterna
document_data.mainbody: The '''Vistani language''', which was properly called the '''patterna''', was the common language spoken by most [[Vistani]]. It was a creole language, being a mixture of words from [[Common]], several [[humanoid]] languages, and unique slang. It was considered rather complex, owing to it being conveyed by context and intonation rather than by straight definitions or root words. It was also composed of many concepts,<ref> phrases, and words that had no direct translations into Common or other tongues. And many ordinary words in Common had no direct translations into patterna. Because of all this, there existed no comprehensive [[book]]s on Vistani vocabulary or translation.

Glossary.Captain: The male leader of a Vistani caravan.{{Cite adventurers league/The Seer|8}}
Glossary.doroq: A ritualistic telling of legends and stories around a campfire.{{Cite adventurers league/The Seer|10}}
Glossary.mortu: A Vistani outcast. Translates literally as "undead".<ref>
Glossary.prastonata: A traditional dance performed around a campfire in the evening.
Glossary.raunie: The female leader of a Vistani caravan.
Glossary.tasque: A term used to refer to the Vistani's extended tribal groups.
Glossary.[[vardo]]: A type of round-top [[wagon]] that Vistani typically traveled in and built themselves.

document_data.History: In the {{YearlinkName|1370}}, a group of [[adventurer]]s in the city of [[Ravens Bluff]] were informed by a local Vistani by the name of [[Madam Coth]] to go to the aid of High [[Priest]]ess [[Morlain]] of the [[Palace of Passion]], having foreseen in a nightmare that danger was coming for her. This quest took them beyond the city to a [[Sunite]] spa resort known as the [[Valley of Dolls]], but on the way there they were waylaid by a trap set by a rival priestess,<ref>{{Cite organized play/LC/Light in the Lover's Eye|2-4}} the [[Talontar]] [[Ivy Creeper]].<ref>{{Cite organized play/LC/Light in the Lover's Eye|18}} She set a trap for them in the form of six black disks, each inscribed with writing that helped to focus them into [[summoning]] spots for a variety of [[baatezu]]. These inscriptions were all written in the Vistani language.<ref>{{Cite organized play/LC/Light in the Lover's Eye|8-9}}
